text: and you said this week that you could
understand the anger of many of those
people who voted for Trump what do you
think it's based on is it based on
anti-immigrant feeling or is it based on
economic failure it's anger and left
behind America Michael Moore has
portrayed this very well in his films
he talks about left behind America in
Ohio and all the Rust Belt states of the
United States where corporate America
has de-industrialized made huge profits
out of it and as Bernie Sanders pointed
out put those profits in tax havens
elsewhere and left those communities to
rot Trump decided to use the populist
agenda he blamed Muslims he blamed
Mexicans he blamed women he blamed
anybody he could think of except the
very corporate America that in many ways
he actually represents the same
arguments actually happen all across
Europe well I was going to ask you
because it's very interesting we go
through this period of economic
dislocation where lots of communities
feel left behind and angry and the
protests everywhere you look are going
to parties of the right they're not
going to parties of the left why is that
why is the left failed gentleman it's
time to move on from the Third Way from
the New Labour agenda for the agenda
which was essentially an incorporation
of that free-market liberal economic
thinking which actually processed
deindustrialization in Britain and to a
lesser extent in Germany but to a
greater says the land run so she ate for
the globalization indeed I think I think
it was and I think what's now happening
is a much stronger left movement across
the United States and across Europe
Bernie Sanders garnered a very large
number of votes because of the technical
Court of Merit by the way so I dropped
it could e of one yes I think he
probably could have won now I guess the
other aspect of this and the something
that Donald Trump has talked a lot about
the marine lepen talks about in my
interview with her as well as
protectionism there people who say you
have lost your industries because of
globalism therefore we need to put up
barriers we need to put more tariffs on
foreign cars for goods coming and you
basically agree with that I think we
have to invest in new industries we have
to have an investment strategy and now
I'm putting forward of a national
investment bank to promote good quality
manufacturing industry we also have to
have fair trade agreements so when we
import goods they should be produced to
the same in
mental standards waived respect we would
want human rights agendas to be on that
and trade agenda so it's not about
closing down trade
it's about fair trade is there a silver
lining for you
in brexit in this in the sense that we
can now do our own new trade agreements
with India China and so forth and put in
human rights put in environmental
protection in a new way into those deals
I'm already working on potential trade
agreements that we could make with other
countries the human rights agenda the
environmental agenda the sustainability
agenda those things are very important
but I'm also working very hard on an
investment strategy for industry and
working with many Left parties across
Europe who are themselves also opposed
to the austerity agenda that's been put
forward look at it this way
over the past six years average wages in
Britain have stagnated or fallen most
families are three and a half thousand
pounds a year worse off than they were
five years six years ago public services
have been cut why is the achievement of
six years of austerity other than cut
public services hospital waiting lists
overcrowding in so many places we need
an investment agenda we need to go
forward on the idea the public
intervention actually can grow our
economy not stagnated now you've talked
about Donald Trump demonizing foreigners
including of course South Americans and
Hispanics your own wife is is Mexican so
this must feel fairly personal to you
and yet as a possible future prime
minister you may well have to deal with
Donald Trump wonder how you feel about
I'm looking forward to the conversation
between my wife and Donald Trump she is
a proud Mexican and she's proud to live
here as well and all of us want to live
in a world where you actually tolerate
and deal with each other now how she and
her family feel about the possibility of
a wall going up between Mexico and the
United States absolute anger and outrage
Donald Trump should grow up and
recognize the American economy actually
depends on migrant labor last year they
had a day without Mexicans they
certainly noticed it and I think the
treatment of Mexico by the United States
just as much as his absurd and abusive
language towards Muslims is something
that has to be challenged and should
be challenged now he has been highly
successful obviously in challenging this
anger and it is partly directed against
immigration and what you have said
suggests that you think that voters who
go along with that have been conned or
fooled or a victim of false
consciousness or something is that not
slightly fraternizing no it's not
patronizing at all I just think that the
blame should be put where it belongs and
that is the corporate investment
decisions that have done so much damage
to industry all over Europe including
obviously in Britain but particularly in
France and other countries in Europe but
we also have to be aware that we have to
deal with it undercutting Len McCluskey
made some very good points about this
last week that accompanies that bring in
wholesale migrant labor to destroy local
working agreements destroy trade union
recognition undercut wages that's got to
end
that's why I've supported the agency
workers directive and why in the
referendum campaign I made a great deal
of emphasis on the question of posting
of workers which is where you bring a
group of workers from here put them here
in order to destroy local working
arrangements and also where there's been
a big impact on on communities its local
government that needs to be properly
funded in order to deal with the needs
do you think your message is going to
cut through to those said to be able to
how people get these figures it's said
that 9 million labour voters voted for
brexit and so well then a lot of them
were concerned about immigration and
they may simply hear what you're saying
as the voice of the metropolitan liberal
elite or establishment it doesn't really
understand how radically communities
have been changed by immigration up down
the north coast for instance communities
have been hit by deindustrialization hit
by deregulation hit by the Thatcherite
reagan model of economics in 1980s it
still plays out in former mining
community in many other places whether
systemic unemployment or underemployment
low wages low levels of investment and
poor and poor industrial development so
we need a government that is prepared to
invest regionally that does have a
regionally based investment bank that
does deal with those social issues
communities coming together to improve
higher education health and housing work
better together blaming
minorities doesn't build houses Kirstin
who's now in your front later he thought
overall generally speaking immigration
should be lower than it is at the moment
do you agree with them I think it will
be lower if we deal with the issues of
wage undercutting deal with the issues
of exploitation but I think we should
also recognize that the migrants that
have come to this country work the mines
that come to this country contribute and
pay taxes actually our National Health
Service would simply not survive without
the level of migrant labour and migrant
doctors and others that are here because
we haven't invested enough in high
skills within our own economy so it's
not your policy to push immigration down
but you think as a result of your
policies immigration will come down
absolutely I think the policies will
help a great deal and also working with
other parties across Europe because I'm
inviting all the socialist parties
across Europe and trade unions to come
together in London in early February so
that we have a good working relationship
with them many of those parties are
either in government absolutely were in
government in coalition they will help
us get the kind of deal that we need on
market access to Europe in the future
when we leave the EU now I've been
interviewing marine lepen rather
controversially this week Christiane
Amanpour was pointing out that because
of the the change in in the electoral
world at the moment it is perfectly
possible this woman will become French
president next year she's very anti NATO
she's very anti the EU she's Pro
protectionist and she's a hard right
nationalist politician how would the
world change do you think we had marine
lepen as president well she uses awful
and absurd language in France against
Muslims I was just talking to a group of
demonstrators outside this morning over
here very angry at the language she's
used against Muslims and others in
France and so she uses this populism
against minorities in order to get
herself elected the reality is she does
not have an economic answer so the
problems faced by left communities in
France any more than you kip has an
economic answer to the Left Behind
Communities in Britain it's only
communities coming together public
investment they can actually deal with
the economic fundamental economic
justices that are getting worse not
better across Europe now you keep
distance themselves you mentioned you
have just now from the National Front
but marine lepen said in the interview
that she sees the two of them as being
quite similar in many ways do you agree
with that I think they probably are
because they both attempt the same
shallow populist nasty appeal because
once you let this nasty nasty thing out
of the box called xenophobia and
intolerance it's very hard to put it
back it's up to the left it's up to the
democratic forces in society to say the
only way forward is society's coming
together the only way forward is to
build institutions like the National
Health Service the same approach we
should take towards industrial
development in our own country the other
thing where she and Putin clearly agree
on is that NATO is a more of a problem
than a solution and they're both quite
understanding as it were of Vladimir
Putin's posture what do you think about
that well I have many many criticisms of
Putin of the human rights abuses in
Russia and of the militarization of
society however I do think there has to
be a process that we try and
demilitarize the border between what are
now the NATO States and Russia so that
we drive apart those forces keep them
further keep them further apart in order
to bring about some kind of
accommodation we can't descend into a
new Cold War absolutely but you think
it's really very simply Trump is good
for the Russian relationship at least
well I'm not quite sure of Donald
Trump's personal economic relationship
with Russia but he clearly thinks he can
have a good relationship with Putin on
the basis that Putin is a strong leader
it's not about strong leaders it's about
strong movements towards coexistence and
towards peace we seem to be moving back
to the language of the 1990s when the
Organization for Security and
Cooperation in Europe should have been
the preeminent grouping maybe that
grouping could be along alongside the
coast of Europe of forum by which
relations can be improved with Russia
but we do have to condemn the human
rights abuses in Russia we do have to
condemn many aspects of Russian foreign
policy can I come back to the big
domestic issue at the moment which is
article 50 and when that's triggered
because there's been
some confusion your party in your front
benchers have said that they will not
block article 50 in the House of Commons
but they expect that to be something
they can amend and debate so there's
lots of things you have has been
suggesting that in the press are red
lines view about worker protection and
so forth
can I ask you straightforwardly if you
don't get article 50 amended as you
would like
Theresa Mayes brexit policy amended as
you would like it would you block
article 50 in the House of Commons we
respect the referendum we voted for the
referendum the result was the result we
got it wasn't the one we want it but we
have to respect it therefore there's
going to be a depart from the European
Union as I pointed out there's going to
be relations with Europe in the future
that's why I'm building these close
relationships with socialist parties
across Europe we will demand that we
have market access workers protection
consumer protection environmental
protection justice issues through the
European Court we will not separate the
bringing in of article 50 but we will be
holding the government to account on it
during the process up to March when
article 50 starts but also during the
negotiating period and the negotiating
period means that we can go behind the
wire as well and work with colleagues
all across Europe to make sure that we
do get market X is half of Britain's
exports go to Europe so if I come back
to the point if you can't or you decide
you on a principled position you will
not block article 50 so that will go
through the House of Commons how are you
going to impose your red lines Ontario
we still have the will still be
demanding in Parliament will still be
voting in Parliament will still be
building alliances in Parliament to
demand the government stick to the
points that I've laid out and indeed the
court decision means that Parliament now
has a role in this obviously depending
on the appeal but we will continue
demanding the whole point about market
access and about workers rights during
the referendum campaign some of those on
the leave side said there was going to
be a bonfire of regulations they've kind
of reduced the rhetoric on that a bit
I don't want any bonfire of regulations
I want the protections we've achieved
through European Union membership to
continue and be put into British law and
I want market access to Europe one more
local matter the possibility of large
members of militant what was Millicent
coming back into the labour party people
like Derek Hatton
p-taff and those kind of people has been
raised I wonder what your attitude would
be to like having those people back
inside the Labour Party well if they're
not in a proscribed organization then
clearly people are free to join the
party if they are in an organization
that's on a prescription list then
they're not that's a matter of the
national executive and our process but
look at it another way there are now
more than 550,000 individual members the
party the three million affiliated
members of the party there is a vast
actually politically very broad and very
diverse membership of the party United
on the idea that our party offers an
economic alternative to left behind to
broken Britain to poverty Britain your
party has been growing the numbers
you're getting in the opinion polls
across the electorate as a whole have
not even fallen when does that start to
change I think it's changing already
actually by election Council by election
results are varied across the country
but I give an example not so far away
from here in one's worth ten percent
rise in the Labour vote last week gains
of a cup of seats in Scotland last month
we have varied results across the
country but I tell you this we are
putting forward an alternative economic
strategy a policy of social social
justice attacking the government on the
NHS attacking the government on the
underfunding of mental health services
as the points Richard Dannic made about
the mental health conditions of former
soldiers where for an inclusive society
that actually cares for all doesn't have
anyone left behind
